title: Jobless Rate Falls To 5.4% As Pay Growth Eases
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Oct 14, 2015, 13:36 BST - UK Markets close in 2 hrs 54 mins Jobless Rate Falls To 5.4% As Pay Growth Eases By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 43 minutes ago View Photo 

The jobless rate has hit its lowest level since mid-2008 but growth in pay awards is showing signs of slowing. 
The Office for National Statistics (ONS) said unemployment fell by 79,000 to 1.77 million in the three months to August. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) helped the jobless rate decline to 5.4%, the ONS said. 
The figures are welcome for the Government as unemployment rose over the two previous periods. 
The ONS said the recovery in employment was enough to help the UK to a new employment record. 
While total pay awards were found to be rising at an annual rate of 3% over the three months to August - regular pay, which excludes bonuses, slipped to 2.8% from 2.9% the previous month. 
A rise of 3% had been forecast by economists. 
It could be a sign of nerves about the future health of the UK economy as many key markets endure a slowdown. 
Sam Hill, senior UK economist at RBC Capital Markets, said there were clear signs of an imbalance. 
"Manufacturing sector wages are up just 1.7% whilst some parts of the service sector, including wholesale and retail, are seeing pay gains of 4.8%," he said. 
However, pay growth continues to outstrip the cost of living. 
The ONS said on Tuesday that lower food and fuel costs in September had sparked a further period of negative inflation - falling prices - a scenario which bolsters household spending power. 
While the Government sought to capitalise on the figures as evidence its handling of the economy was bearing fruit, the GMB union's general secretary was more fearful of what the future holds. 
Paul Kenny said: "The job losses at Redcar steel works and JCB are dark clouds on the horizon. 
"Employment growth is likely to slow as large cuts in public sector employment kick in and as lower-paid workers seek more hours to make up for the nearly £30 per week cuts they face in tax credits ."
